title.narrative: DETECT: Integrated Space Technology Vector Control for Enhancing community health and resilience against escalating climatic disruptions

description.narrative: Malaria and dengue have a major impact on the health and development prospects of remote communities in developing countries, where conventional mosquito control strategies are failing. Building on 20 years of community engagement in Guyana our space technology solution will be designed and developed in collaboration with communities and local stakeholders. We will combine Synthetic Aperture Radar image analysis, ground station and remotely controlled UAV sensing, and precision UAV spraying to deliver an early warning and automated vector control system. Simultaneously, we will build on our established 'digital health' partner network within Commonwealth countries in order to expand operations in the Operational Phase.

Mosquito-borne diseases have a major impact on developing countries. In 2018, there were an estimated 228 million cases and 405,000 deaths from malaria alone. DETECT will integrate satellite, air-borne and ground-based sensing to detect where mosquitoes are most likely to breed. Building on 20 years of community engagement in Guyana, the DETECT space technology solution will be designed and developed in collaboration with communities and local stakeholders. The aim is to apply space science innovations to existing products to provide communities and key decision-makers with a higher-resolution and more responsive map of vector population risk and to direct when and where community-based vector control interventions should occur. Through satellite communications, the system will then dispatch ‘sprayer drones’ to these high-risk areas to release biocontrol agents – killing mosquito larvae without affecting other species.
